message: I only really have found it useful in css files using the {{{ and }}} method of folding to separate the css rules into groupings.
It seems like a neat idea, but with how fast it is to move around, I find folding cumbersome to maintain. In what situations is folding most useful?
If you write python at all I recommend the jpython_fold script.

I use folding all the time with HTML, Python, CSS, JS and pretty much anything else I edit. The key to me, though, isn't using folding as you're creating a file or reading the file, but to fold away the bits that don't pertain to your current task.

Folding is excellent as long as you use the right method for what you are trying to accomplish.  I find foldmarkers to be sufficient for config files, however I don't want that crap scattered through my source code (although I do this with vimscript).
I mostly use folding in DIFF views. The folding is hiding the parts that are equal in both files.
Sometimes I use it to explore code or classes in particular.
Folding everything, unfolding a class so that I see the method definitions but not the implementation.
@rson's last post is the truth. much MUCH better folding than the stock implementations.
As a side note, does anyone use horizontal folding? Or you just use discipline in keeping your lines shorter than n-columns?
@emk: discipline :) but as a python coder, it's not hard.
I turn off word wrap, so long lines will annoy more, which helps with the discipline to keep lines short

I'm a web developer coding in PHP (at work) and Python (django) most of the time on my spare time. Haven't gotten around to use folding and playing around with it (mainly using python and foldmethod=indent) I can't really see the charm. For me it seems to be a bit in the way more than helping. Or is there some way to not autofold on indent but still be able to manually fold using this method (hiding away as you code along)?

@xintron there are many foldmethods you can use.  With manual you can just highlight some code you want to fold away and type `zf`.  These types of folds don't persist though unless you use sessions/views or something.

I use folding to fold away comments in source code.  I only use comments for API documentation, and I try to keep the first sentence a good description of what the method is for and what it does.  I then have a fold method that extracts that sentence and hides everything else.  Here’s what it looks like:
http://i.imgur.com/9lMJN.png
(Uh, sorry about the multiple posts – this isn’t helping, I know – and are images really supposed to be rendered with such poor quality?)
oh wait... maybe I do. in text files. My code is clean enough that folding doesn't make a difference!
I don't use folding
Folding always seems to distract me, I get this crazy compulsion to fold everything away and my productivity just takes a dive off of a cliff

Use "zi", "zn" and "zN" to toggle folding on & off.  Sometimes I use folding, sometimes I don't.  Sometimes I use fdm=indent (Python), sometimes fdm=marker (CSS), sometimes fdm=syntax (C).  Getting familiar with fold commands like "zc" (close), "zO" (open recursively) and "]z" (jump to end of current fold) are important; they make you go a lot faster and decrease the cost of switching between [no]foldenable and the different modes.
